1460268464107573259.text: Under the Treaties of Velasco Zavala was appointed a peace commissioner to accompany Santa Anna to Mexico City, but returned to his home in poor health shortly thereafter. He resigned the vice presidency on October 17, 1836.

1460268462673178628.text: Zavala's legislative, executive, ministerial, and diplomatic experience, together with his education and linguistic ability, uniquely qualified him for the role he was to play in the drafting of the constitution of the Republic of Texas.

1460268461599383559.text: When he learned that Santa Anna had assumed dictatorial powers in 1834, Zavala denounced his former ally, resigned his post, and eventually went to Texas. Although he first advocated the cause of Mexican Federalism, he soon became an active supporter of the independence movement.

1460268460278226955.text: In the 1820s he helped establish a republican government in newly independent Mexico, but was forced into exile in 1830. Zavala returned to Mexico in 1832 and was named to serve as the first minister plenipotentiary of the Mexican legation in Paris.

1460268459217063941.text: His support of democratic reforms led to his imprisonment in 1814 in Veracruz, where he gained enough knowledge from reading medical textbooks to qualify him to practice medicine upon his release in 1817. He also taught himself to read English during his imprisonment.
